author: Agencias
title: Pedro Sánchez aplaude la ruptura del PP y Vox: "Un día grande para España"
text:
Pedro Sánchez aplaude la ruptura del PP y Vox: "Un día grande para España"
El jefe del Ejecutivo afirma en Washington que lo importante es que se va a beneficiar la mayoría social de los españoles
Vox confirma que rompe con el PP en las cinco comunidades donde gobiernan en coalición
El presidente del Gobierno, Pedro Sánchez, ha celebrado la salida de Vox de los gobiernos autonómicos que compartía con el Partido Popular asegurando que "hoy es un gran día para España" y ha ligado que el PSOE garantice la estabilidad de los ejecutivos del PP a las políticas que desarrollen. Sánchez se ha referido a la ruptura de los gobiernos del PP y Vox en la rueda de prensa con la que ha cerrado su agenda en Washington para participar en la cumbre de la OTAN.
Para el jefe del Ejecutivo, más allá de quién pueda beneficiarse políticamente de esa ruptura, lo importante es que se va a beneficiar la mayoría social de los españoles.
"España es hoy un país mejor, y, por tanto, no puedo ocultar mi alegría y mi felicidad (...) bien está lo que bien acaba", ha recalcado antes de insistir en que celebra que acabe algo que jamás tuvo que suceder en España, la entrada de la ultraderecha en gobiernos de comunidades.
La "prueba del algodón" de la ley de extranjería
Ahora cree que el PP debe hacerse la pregunta de si está dispuesto a romper con las políticas que ha aprobado con Vox, y considera que el principal partido de la oposición tiene una oportunidad y "la prueba del algodón" en la reforma de la ley de extranjería.
Al respecto ha señalado que el hecho cierto es que hay 6.000 menores extranjeros en Canarias y hay que dar una solución, momento en el que ha subrayado que ser un partido de estado exige dar soluciones a los problemas y los desafíos de los ciudadanos vivan donde vivan.
También ha reclamado al PP que sea quien tome la iniciativa y rompa los acuerdos con Vox que tienen en ayuntamientos de toda España.
Ante la pregunta de si estaría dispuesto a que el PSOE garantizara la estabilidad de los gobiernos del PP de los que sale Vox, como han defendido ya algunos dirigentes del partido, Sánchez se ha limitado a señalar que en los sitios en los que el PSOE es oposición va a seguir haciendo una oposición constructiva, como ha afirmado que ha hecho siempre.
"Por tanto, dependerá de las políticas que proponga el Gobierno autonómico de turno a la Asamblea correspondiente el que cuente con el apoyo o no del Partido Socialista", ha añadido.
Ha insistido el presidente del Gobierno en que la estrategia del líder del PP, Alberto Núñez Feijóo, de gobernar con la ultraderecha ha fracasado y eso supone una gran noticia haciendo un balance de las cosas que han aprobado esos gobiernos autonómicos que compartían.
Entre ellas ha citado la ley de concordia aprobada este jueves en las Cortes Valencianas que deroga la anterior ley de Memoria Democrática y que ha dicho que contraviene el Derecho Internacional Humanitario tal y como alertó Naciones Unidas.
Por ello ha reiterado que lo importante más allá de la ruptura de los gobiernos autonómicos es saber qué políticas va a hacer el PP y si este partido va a ser el que va a romper ahora los gobiernos locales que comparte con Vox.
También te puede interesar
Lo último
SAN FERMÍN 2024
[]https://www.diariodesevilla.es/sociedad/herido-asta-toro-sexto-encierro_0_2001559647.html

author: Matilda Rudd
title: Get four of Alpha-H’s best-selling serums for under $100 in the brand’s discovery set
text: [Alpha-H](https://go.linkby.com/JDBDKEIH/collections/serums/products/vitamin-discovery-kit#product-information) is almost in a class of its own when it comes to revolutionary skincare products. The Aussie brand is well-known for its “ [liquid gold](https://go.linkby.com/JDBDKEIH/collections/serums/products/vitamin-discovery-kit#product-information)” exfoliant and cleansing balm that “wipes away” makeup. But it’s the collection of serums you’ll definitely want to be trialling next. Supermarkets, shopping and deals: [Sign up for newsletters ](https://7news.com.au/newsletters) Instead of spending hundreds of dollars on the full-sized bottles only to discover they’re difficult to travel with, the brand has released a [$99.95 Vitamin Discovery Kit](https://go.linkby.com/JDBDKEIH/collections/serums/products/vitamin-discovery-kit#product-information) so you can pick and choose your favourites in miniature form. The [serums are formulated to firm](https://go.linkby.com/JDBDKEIH/collections/serums/products/vitamin-discovery-kit#product-information), hydrate, brighten and restore your skin, all for under $100. Whether you’re new to serums, want to try before you buy, are ready to take your skin cycling to the next level or need a complete travel-friendly routine, the [Alpha-H Vitamin Discovery Kit](https://go.linkby.com/JDBDKEIH/collections/serums/products/vitamin-discovery-kit#product-information) has you covered. It contains a [Vitamin A, Vitamin B, Vitamin C and Vitamin E serum](https://go.linkby.com/JDBDKEIH/collections/serums/products/vitamin-discovery-kit#product-information) in pastel coloured bottles so you can easily tell them apart in the bathroom cabinet. So what can each of them [do for your skin](https://go.linkby.com/JDBDKEIH/collections/serums/products/vitamin-discovery-kit#product-information)? - Vitamin A: An age-defying serum to help firm and plump. - Vitamin B: An all-rounder serum to hydrate and help strengthen your skin barrier. - Vitamin C: An antioxidant serum to help brighten and protect. - Vitamin E: A first-aid serum to help nourish, calm and soothe. After cleansing your face, apply three to four drops of your [chosen serum](https://go.linkby.com/JDBDKEIH/collections/serums/products/vitamin-discovery-kit#product-information) to the face, neck and decolletage depending on what skin concerns you’re facing that day. Once the skin is touch try, follow with a moisturiser or SPF. “The oils are easily absorbed and make my skin feel soft and subtle,” [one buyer of the Vitamin Discovery Set wrote](https://go.linkby.com/JDBDKEIH/collections/serums/products/vitamin-discovery-kit#product-information). “Great products. Perfect to gift,” wrote another. To purchase and trial the kit for yourself head to [Alpha-H’s website here](https://go.linkby.com/JDBDKEIH/collections/serums/products/vitamin-discovery-kit#product-information).

author: RANDY DOCKENDORF randy.dockendorf@yankton.net
title: Yankton Area Braces For A Lion Of A Storm | Community | yankton.net
text: What a wonderful winter we’re having this spring. The calendar says it’s spring, but a wintry blast may roll across the region into early next week, according to the National Weather Service (NWS). A mixture of light snow, rain, freezing rain and wintry mix was forecast to occur across most of the area through this morning (Friday). The most intense activity lies ahead, according to Tim Masters, a meteorological technician with the NWS office in Sioux Falls. “This (early rain-snow mix) is the teaser stuff ahead of the main big trough of low pressure coming out of the west,” he said. “It will start coming in Friday night and will persist through probably Tuesday.” Much uncertainty remains on the amount and type of precipitation, Masters said, but some things appear certain. “This is a spring version of a major winter storm. It’s going to be long-lived, several days of rain, snow and maybe some wintry mix in there,” he said. “What complicates things is we’re going to be right around freezing. If the freezing sets up a little south, we’ll see more snow. If it’s further north, we’ll see more rain.” Because of that uncertainty, southeast South Dakota and northeast Nebraska could see widely varying conditions during the storm system, Masters said. “Yankton should be on the southern end (of the trough) and get mostly rain and sleet but won’t get into the heavier snow,” he said. “But there’s still a small probability that Yankton could get more than six inches (of snow).” WHAT COULD HAPPEN The NWS has been tracking the system in the western United States as it moves across the nation, Masters said. Various models predict different paths for the system, which could mean a major difference for the Yankton region. “There is a lot of uncertainty where the rain-snow line is going to be and what we’ll see for (the amount and type of) precipitation,” he said. Currently, the two main tracks are following Interstate 80, through Nebraska and Iowa, and Interstate 90, through South Dakota and Minnesota. “We know it’s working west to east; it’s a matter of how far north or south,” Masters said. In the coming days, he advises against planning outdoor activities. In addition, he encourages travelers to change or cancel their plans, if needed. A DAILY BREAKDOWN The NWS website provides an estimate of when the second, larger storm could arrive and what it can mean for the Yankton region. To the west, Lake Andes could begin receiving snow shortly after midnight Saturday, continuing with either additional snow or a wintry mix through Tuesday. Yankton could begin receiving snow around 6 a.m. Saturday. The outlook calls for the system to continue with a combination of rain and wintry mix through Monday night, with snow expected to return Tuesday. For southeast South Dakota, today’s outlook calls for partly sunny skies with a high near 40. The breezy conditions include a north wind of 15-20 miles per hour (mph), gusting to 25 mph. On Saturday, the outlook calls for a 30% chance of snow with cloudy skies and a high near 37. Wind gusts could reach 30 mph. In the nighttime, the chance of precipitation is 70% with new snow accumulations of less than a half-inch possible. Sunday’s outlook calls for a 100% chance of precipitation with new snow accumulations of less than a half-inch possible. The east-southeast wind of 25-35 mph could gust to 40 mph. On Sunday night, the chance of precipitation remains high at 90% with rain and snow. Some thunder is also possible. On Monday, the outlook calls for a 90% chance of precipitation with a high near 34, and a 50% chance of snow that night. The storm tapers down Tuesday, with a 20% chance of snow before 1 p.m. The outlook calls for mostly sunny, with a high near 24 and blustery conditions. For northeast Nebraska, the NWS outlook follows a similar pattern. The storm system will bring widespread precipitation to the region Saturday evening through Monday. This will include chances for accumulating snow, especially over northeast Nebraska. The first snow chance is a 30-40% chance of accumulating snow Saturday morning, mainly along the Nebraska-South Dakota border. The better chance for snow accumulation, ranging from a 50-70% chance in far northeast Nebraska down to a 20-30% chance along Interstate 80, will be from late Sunday night into Tuesday morning. The NWS noted the forecast is likely to change as the storm track becomes more apparent. NEEDED MOISTURE Given the prolonged drought, any precipitation is welcome in the northern Great Plains, according to Colorado assistant state climatologist Becky Bolinger. “We’ve had a very mild winter,” she said during Thursday’s NOAA webinar covering the Rocky Mountains to the Great Lakes. As a result, the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) has recorded low flows of rivers and streams across the region, she said. In addition, the snowpack in Montana, which feeds the Missouri River, has been running at low levels. “There are concerns with the very mild winter and low snowpack in the Missouri River basin, that these flows could likely go lower,” she said. The drought conditions also heighten concerns about wildfires, she noted. The weekly U.S. Drought Monitor report lists all of southeast South Dakota and northeast Nebraska at least abnormally dry, with Lincoln and Minnehaha counties in moderate drought. Looking at the incoming weather system, Masters said the same conditions can produce different results now than during mid-winter. “Below normal temperatures in mid- to late March are different than January,” he said. “Now, ‘below normal’ means more like the 30s, while in January it’s much colder. And if we do get snow, it would be wet snow, which is harder to blow around.” Despite the spring date on the calendar, Masters said travelers shouldn’t become complacent and should travel fully prepared, including a full tank of gas. “We’re advising people to treat this like it was January,” he said. March entered with unseasonably mild weather, with the old saying, “In like a lamb, out like a lion.” Given the forecast, the adage will apparently come true, Masters said. “This (storm) would be the lion,” he said. Follow @RDockendorf on Twitter (X).

author: S24H
title: Las Oriónidas iluminarán el cielo de Salamanca hasta noviembre
text:
Un gran espectáculo, en el que se mezclan la velocidad y el brillo, adornará el cielo de Salamanca hasta el 7 de noviembre. Se trata de las famosas Oriónidas, una lluvia de meteoros que se produce cada año en otoño cuando los restos del cometa Halley pasan por la Tierra.
No obstante, este 2024, el evento astronómico será todo un reto ya que el pico de actividad más alto será el 21 de octubre, coincidiendo con la luna en su fase menguante. Según detalla ElTiempo, en ese momento el satélite se encontrará iluminado al 83%, dificultando la visibilidad, sobre todo, de las estrellas fugaces más débiles. Las más brillantes se podrán apreciar incluso como "bolas de fuego con estelas luminosas".
En su máximo apogeo, los amantes de las estrellas podrán apreciar hasta 20 meteoros por hora viajando a una velocidad de 66 kilómetros por segundo.
¿Cómo ver las Oriónidas?
Para apreciar esta fascinante lluvia de estrellas se recomienda acudir a un lugar sin contaminación lumínica entre el anochecer y el amanecer, donde se recomienda esperar unos 20 minutos hasta que la vista se acostumbre.
No es necesario emplear telescopios o similares ya que se pueden apreciar a simple vista. Además, estas estrellas proceden de la constelación de Orión, por lo que aparecerán cercana a ella, que se eleva en el este después de medianoche.

author: Eric Heyl
title: Popular Pittsburgh Restaurant Shutting Its Doors
text:
Restaurants & Bars
Popular Pittsburgh Restaurant Shutting Its Doors
The owner of a Pittsburgh restaurant is shuttering his eatery for family reasons.
PITTSBURGH, PA — Bonfire is being extinguished.
Bonfire Food & Drink on the South Side will be closing in the coming weeks after owner and chef Chris Bonsili decided not to renew the restaurant's lease. Bonfire had occupied the East Carson Street space for the past six years.
"After the unexpected passing of my father this past year, I’ve spent the last several months reevaluating the time, energy, and schedule that being the chef/owner of an independent restaurant requires," Bonfili said in a Facebook post.
Find out what's happening in Pittsburghfor free with the latest updates from Patch.
"Although my passion for the business still runs deep, my commitment and desire to live the chef life has waned. With my children in high school and middle school, I’m looking forward to focusing on my family and living more of the dad life for this next chapter."
Bonsili did not offer a specific closure date, saying "We still have a little time before the fire goes out for good." The restaurant's hours will be changing in its final days; the revised hours will be posted on social media.
Find out what's happening in Pittsburghfor free with the latest updates from Patch.
Get more local news delivered straight to your inbox.
Sign up for free Patch newsletters and alerts.

author: pp_aB59t3KmFcCDkghjfReoi0
title: ‘The cameras have been good for us’: Mandated police body cameras a positive, but not a panacea
text: ‘The cameras have been good for us’: Mandated police body cameras a positive, but not a panacea When they gear up for their first shift of 2024, police officers in 30 Illinois municipalities — 20 of them suburbs — will be strapping on body-worn cameras not only in line with their departments’ policies, but also state law. Under the the 2021 SAFE-T Act, officers in towns of more than 50,000 must wear the cameras when on duty starting Monday and have them recording whenever engaged in any law enforcement encounter or activity. The state mandate extends to towns under 50,000 on Jan. 1, 2025. For officers in most of the affected towns, including Arlington Heights, Mount Prospect, Palatine, Schaumburg and Des Plaines, it’ll be business as usual. They’ve been wearing body cameras for months, and in some cases years. Department leaders we spoke with say the cameras have been a positive addition, citing their effectiveness as a training tool and their ability to provide clarity if an officer’s actions are called into question. “It helps present an unbiased view of what happened when someone calls to complain,” said Arlington Heights Police Chief Nicholas Pecora, whose agency first deployed body-worn cameras in March 2022. “It supports the officer’s position the large majority of the time.” “The cameras have been good for us,” added Mount Prospect police Cmdr. Bart Tweedie, whose department has been using them since March 2021. “It gives us more information and allows us to see an incident from the officer’s perspective.” Even with those benefits, some see body-worn cameras falling short of the high expectations created in the wake of the police killing of George Floyd in 2020 and other high-profile instances of officer misconduct. Cameras’ abilities to reduce use-of-force incidents and citizen complaints remain unproven and, as we’ve seen in some suburban cases, video footage doesn’t always settle public debate about an officer’s actions. That was the case in March 2018, when an Elgin police lieutenant shot and killed a 34-year-old woman during a standoff on Interstate 90. Video footage showed the woman, Decynthia Clements, getting out of her vehicle and lunging toward officers with a knife before she was shot. The shooting sparked months of protests nonetheless, with protesters disputing police statements that officers needed to use deadly force. “One of the things we need to do is manage public expectations of what video is capable of,” said Seth Stoughton, a former police officer turned law professor at the University of South Carolina. He’s [researched and written](https://scholarcommons.sc.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2184&context=law_facpub) about the use of body-worn cameras and testified as a use-of-force expert during the trial of former Minneapolis police officer Derrick Chauvin, who was convicted in Floyd’s killing. “It may provide us with more information and insight, or it could also be completely useless.” Culture, not cameras Stoughton, faculty director of South Carolina’s [Excellence in Policing & Public Safety Program](https://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/law/centers/epps/index.php), noted that important factors like distances between people and the pace of events often can be hard to judge from a video, especially one shot from the torso of a police officer engaged in a use-of-force incident. “Video is in no way perfect evidence. It’s simply another piece of evidence.” he said. “We just have to avoid the mistake of thinking it can resolve every discrepancy.” Research into whether the presence of body cameras reduces use of force and citizen complaints has been mixed. Studies of police in [Washington, D.C.](https://crimesolutions.ojp.gov/ratedprograms/644#1-0), [New York City](https://crimesolutions.ojp.gov/ratedprograms/769) and [Milwaukee](https://crimesolutions.ojp.gov/ratedprograms/1788) showed body-worn cameras had no significant impact on the number of times officers used force. But similar research in [Las Vegas](https://crimesolutions.ojp.gov/ratedprograms/640), [Phoenix](https://crimesolutions.ojp.gov/ratedprograms/730) and [Rialto, California](https://crimesolutions.ojp.gov/ratedprograms/499), showed cameras may have reduced complaints and/or the use of force. For Stoughton, those results show it’s less about the cameras than it is the policies and practices surrounding them, and the culture of the police department using them. “Officers who take pride in their work, are good public servants and who use their powers judiciously don’t need a body-worn camera to prevent them from engaging in misconduct,” he said. On the other hand, Stoughton noted, the Minneapolis officers involved in the Floyd killing and the Memphis cops charged in January’s killing of Tyre Nichols were wearing body cameras at the time “For officers who are prone to misconduct, we’ve learned the presence of a body-worn camera doesn’t stop them,” he said. What policies and practices can build an effective culture around body cameras? Stoughton said key elements include clear requirements about when they must be worn and recording, supervisory oversight to make sure officers are adhering to those requirements, and a willingness to share footage with the public, whether it’s flattering of not. “(Cameras) do not provide accountability,” he added. “They are a tool that can help provide accountability. It’s up to (police) supervisors to create accountability.” Stoughton, who describes himself as a fan of body cameras despite their limitations, said like any other tool, they can be used for a good purpose, a bad purpose, or be made useless. “They aren’t a magical fix to what is a sociological issue, which is the culture of a department and its relationship to the community,” he said. Costs Back in the suburbs, police leaders say that if there is a downside to body-worn cameras, it’s the time and money their departments must spend buying and maintaining the equipment, storing and managing video, and responding to Freedom of Information Act requests for footage. Arlington Heights in 2021 inked a five-year, $1.3 million contract with Scottsdale, Arizona-based Axon Enterprises to acquire body and dashboard cameras, cover their maintenance and provide cloud-based storage of video. Buffalo Grove reached a similar deal — but for 10 years — with Axon at a cost of $1.4 million. Under state law, video must be preserved for at least 90 days — and longer if the recording is the subject of a complaint or shows use of force or potential misconduct. And while most routine footage is not subject to public disclosure requirements, police must release video of an incident involving force, a shooting, an arrest or a death or injury. But before doing so, they must edit the video to blur out the faces of anyone who was not directly involved in the incident. Mount Prospect’s Tweedie said two of his department’s full-time clerks spend a substantial amount of their time just maintaining video and responding to disclosure requests. “The time and costs have been a drawback, but overall it’s been a net positive for our department,” he said. * Do you have a tip or a comment? Email us at copsandcrime@dailyherald.com. [terms of service](https://www.dailyherald.com/info/terms-of-service/#conduct), click the "flag" link in the lower-right corner of the comment box. To find our more, read our [FAQ](https://www.dailyherald.com/info/comments/).

author: Ángela Poves
title: Carla Pereyra se come a besos a Simeone: así celebraron la victoria del Atleti
text: Carla Pereyra es una habitual en los encuentros del Atlético de Madrid y se ha convertido en el mayor apoyo de su marido, Diego Pablo Simeone. El conjunto colchonero se jugaba este miércoles los cuartos de final de la Champions League contra el Inter de Milán. Un partido que acabó con la victoria del equipo madrileño y con la argentina, eufórica, abalanzándose sobre los brazos de su marido. La empresaria no quiso perderse un momento tan importante como este. El conjunto de Simeone celebró la victoria por todo lo alto, pero también lo hizo la influencer. A través de sus redes sociales, Pereyra compartió un vídeo donde abrazaba al Cholo tras el encuentro y besaba con efusividad a su chico. Ver esta publicación en Instagram Una publicación compartida de CARLA PEREYRA (@carla.pereyra15) La realidad es que Carla ha mostrado todas sus facetas: como empresaria, como madre y como esposa. La argentina acompaña a su marido a cada encuentro del equipo colchonero con sus dos hijas en común, Francesca y Valentina. Llevan más de 10 años de relación y pasaron por el altar en el pasado 2019. El secreto de su amor: \"La comunicación\", apuntó la argentina hace unas semanas. No obstante, la modelo recientemente reivindicó su identidad, harta de ser etiquetada como 'la mujer de': \"Necesitamos poner un título a las personas. Yo he evolucionado, cambiado, mejorado y me he preparado\", dijo hace unas semanas. La argentina también despejó las dudas sobre la posibilidad de ampliar la familia, algo que, de momento, descarta porque están inmersos en sus \"proyectos laborales\": \"En estos momentos tengo tantas amigas embarazas que nunca se sabe. Pero soy consciente de que los niños necesitan su tiempo, y en estos momentos estamos muy bien. Cuando las cosas están equilibradas, hay que cuidarlas\", apuntó. Pereyra es uno de los rostros más conocidos del mundo del modelaje, donde se dio a conocer hace ya más de dos décadas. No obstante, Carla también se lanzó con todo al mundo empresarial: creó Carpesim SL, una empresa dedicada al ámbito inmobiliario en zoas lujosas de Madrid.

author: News Desk
title: Brighton 4-2 Tottenham: Seagulls smash sorry Spurs despite late fightback - Football365
text: Brighton 4-2 Tottenham: Seagulls smash sorry Spurs despite late fightback Tottenham were smashed 4-2 by Brighton, who went four goals up, helped by two Joao Pedro penalties, and Spurs could only manage a pair of late consolation goals. Spurs arrived at the Amex Stadium seeking a fourth successive top-flight success to reclaim fourth spot from reigning champions Manchester City. But the north London club were ripped apart as Pedro’s double and Estupinan’s thunderbolt added to Jack Hinshelwood’s opener. Tottenham, who claimed late consolations through substitute Alejo Veliz and Ben Davies, could easily have lost by more as rampant Albion twice hit the woodwork and had a Facundo Buonanotte effort disallowed. Richarlison struck a post for the visitors and was twice denied by the offside flag, while Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg also hit the woodwork. Yet, on this evidence, Champions League qualification looks a distant dream for Ange Postecoglou’s side, who had registered just one point from 15 before their recent upturn in form. Victory lifts Roberto De Zerbi’s hosts above Newcastle into eighth. Depleted were missing eight first-team players while their visitors also had a lengthy list of absentees. One-time Arsenal forward Danny Welbeck should have opened the scoring for Albion inside six minutes when he was twice denied by goalkeeper Guglielmo Vicario, but the Seagulls deservedly edged ahead with 11 minutes on the clock. Tottenham’s porous defence failed to halt Pedro’s mazy waltz across the 18-yard box and his offload was emphatically dispatched into the roof of the net by 18-year-old defender Hinshelwood. Brazilian forward Pedro duly doubled the lead with a spot-kick awarded following VAR intervention. Spurs thought they had escaped when Jan Paul van Hecke’s header from a Pascal Gross corner came back off the right post but replays showed Dejan Kulusevski pulled down Welbeck as he attempted to reach the rebound and Pedro coolly rolled home from 12 yards. Stunned Spurs showed little response and were in danger of falling further behind. James Milner rattled the right post with a superb curling effort before Buonanotte’s clinical finish was flagged offside. The away side almost gifted Brighton a third when Pedro was sent through by a calamitous back-pass from Pedro Porro, only to see his attempted dink pushed wide by Vicario. Postecoglou would undoubtedly have been happy to reach the break only two behind, albeit his side’s predicament nearly improved as Richarlison swept against the outside of the left post in added time. The Brazilian then put the ball in the net having already been ruled offside and then curled wide before again being denied by the flag of assistant referee Darren Cann. Tottenham’s frustration was quickly compounded. Seagulls substitute Estupinan, making his first appearance since November 9 due to injury, did the damage, unleashing a thunderous, dipping effort into the top right corner from around 25 yards following Milner’s short corner. Tormentor-in-chief Pedro rubbed salt into Spurs’ wounds 15 minutes from time by dispatching his second penalty after Evan Ferguson was brought down by Giovani Lo Celso. Veliz’s first goal in English football, after Kulusevski and Son Heung-min capitalised on sloppy Seagulls defending, eased the embarrassment before Davies’ header from a Porro cross increased the anxiety among home fans. But Brighton weathered a frantic nine minutes of added time, during which Hojbjerg hit the base of the right post, to claim the points. READ MORE: [How Premier League teams qualify for Champions League and Europa competitions for 24/25](https://www.football365.com/news/how-premier-league-teams-qualify-for-champions-league-and-europa-competitions-for-24-25)

author: NA
title: Thunderstorms expected in four states until 5pm | The Star
text:
KUALA LUMPUR: Thunderstorms, heavy rain and strong winds are expected in four states until 5pm on Friday, according to the Malaysian Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia).
In a weather warning issued at 2pm on Friday (Nov 1), it said the conditions were expected in Pahang (Bentong), Negri Sembilan (Jelebu, Kuala Pilah, Rembau, Jempol and Tampin) and Melaka.
Meanwhile, in Johor, similar conditions were expected in Tangkak, Kluang, Mersing, Pontian, Kulai, Kota Tinggi and Johor Baru. - Bernama

author: Collins Chong Yew Keat
title: Does China’s Defiance Show The Limits Of US Deterrence In The South China Sea? – Analysis
text:
This year’s annual Balikatan joint military exercises between the Philippines and the United States from April 22 to May 10 was groundbreaking. So was China’s response to it. The exercise areas and the arms deployed to the South China Sea and the Taiwan Strait hotspots were more complex, prompting a surge in Chinese vessel presence in Manila’s western exclusive economic zone and another violent sea incident over a contested reef – exposing Beijing’s defiance amid the Philippine-U.S. alliance’s show of force. The tit-for-tat shows of force escalated tensions in choppy waters and raised questions about the drill’s deterrent value. The symbolism and messages show how parties are digging in, accepting more risk, and shrinking space for diplomacy.
Expanded and evolved allied show of force The 39th Balikatan exercise was billed as the “most effective, most ambitious, and most complicated.” It builds on advances made in past iterations editions of the annual drill, which has become a laboratory for testing new defense concepts and weapons in the field. In 2022, U.S.-made Patriot missiles were inserted by land and sea in Cagayan, one of the Philippines’ northernmost provinces opposite Taiwan.
Last year, live-fire demonstrations of Patriot and Avenger missiles occurred in Zambales, a coastal province facing the West Philippine Sea. For the first time, a sinking exercise (SINKEX) was also conducted with a decommissioned corvette as a mock target hit by volleys from land, air, and sea platforms. The event was also held off Zambales, 235 kilometers from Scarborough Shoal, a contested feature between Manila and Beijing.
This year, the Typhon ground-based missile was featured, with a range of 1600 kilometers. For the first time, Patriot missile launchers were also deployed in Clark, a former U.S. airbase in central Luzon. Whether these arms will eventually be prepositioned to agreed locations under the PH-US Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement (EDCA) bears watching. The Typhon missiles remain in place in undisclosed sites well after the exercise, fueling speculations that they are now stationed in the country. EDCA bases were expanded from five to nine last year, with three new sites in northern Luzon and an additional site in southern Palawan. If they ever get fixed in such places, will China react the same way it did when South Korea allowed the installation of U.S. Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) missiles on its soil? If so, Manila’s waning ties with its big neighbor and largest trade partner may further deteriorate. Beijing condemned the missile deployment. PRC Defence Ministry spokesperson Wu Qian said they “brought huge risks of war into the region,” noting that “intermediate-range missiles are strategic and offensive weapons with a strong Cold War color.”
The external defense and multi-domain orientation of recent Balikatan rounds have been sharpened. This year’s iteration included island protection and retaking , air and missile defense , as well as cybersecurity and information operations. It also saw the debut participation of the Philippine Coast Guard , an agency at the forefront of dealing with an increasingly forceful China in rough waters. U.S. HIMARS rockets were also fired in Palawan, a vanguard province facing the South China Sea. A SINKEX was conducted in President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.’s home province of Ilocos Norte, also in northern Luzon. A Chinese-made former naval tanker became the target, raising conjectures despite explanations that the same was merely coincidental.
Most importantly, for the first time, maritime activities went beyond the country’s 12 nautical-mile territorial seas. France, which hopes to supply Manila with submarines , dispatched a frigate to join their Filipino and American counterparts, who sailed from the Sulu Sea to the South China Sea. Paris’ entry was its first . Fourteen countries, including fellow South China Sea littoral states Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam, also sent observers .
China: defiant and undeterred Manila’s unprecedented moves were met by Beijing’s bold measures. A swell in Chinese government and militia vessels was sighted near Philippine outposts in the South China Sea. This includes three Chinese maritime research vessels spotted in the Second Thomas Shoal, a recent flashpoint between the two neighbors. Another was seen off Catanduanes, way off in the country’s east facing the Pacific Ocean. Four Chinese PLA vessels took turns tailing the allied flotilla consisting of four ships – two Philippine, one American, and one French – conducting multilateral maritime exercises in the South China Sea.
While Balikatan was underway, a new incident happened in Scarborough Shoal. Two Philippine government vessels suffered damage from ramming and water cannons by three Chinese coast guard ships. The confrontation comes at the heels of a March episode wherein a Philippine civilian boat contracted by the military was likewise subjected to high-pressure water blasting by two Chinese coast guard ships.
The expectation that Balikatan, especially with the presence of foreign navies, will compel China to behave properly and restrain from taking assertive actions fumbled. The latest sea incident was denounced by several countries. But beyond flouting international law and reputational costs, China’s defiance bared a strong statement – the upgraded exercise no longer deters her, and nor does Manila’s vigorous presence in the contested sea. Will this trigger the alliance to calibrate response to gray zone actions? Injuries to sailors and damage to property and all, Chinese actions still do not fall beyond the ambit of armed attack that may trigger much-vaunted U.S. pledges of ironclad commitment to its junior ally. The Scarborough Shoal water blasting affair may embolden China to push the envelope further. More untoward instances, in turn, may erode trust in the alliance’s ability to push back beyond rhetorical denunciations.
A more expansive and evolved Balikatan is part of the Philippines’ approach of deepening defense relations with the U.S. and other partners to ward off China. Failure to get satisfactory results may force a rethink. This may play into China’s desire to diminish Manila’s strong bond with its former colonizer and longtime treaty ally and exclude non-regional powers from the intractable sea row.
Yet, close calls and all, disputants still tolerate further risk. Manila remains headstrong with its exposé of Chinese activities in contested waters and taking part in combined activities with allies and partners. Diplomatic protests are piling up with no foreseen high-level dialogue with Beijing. In marked contrast, American and Chinese defense chiefs met on the sidelines of this year’s Shangri-la Dialogue in Singapore last month, the first since 2022. It is part of a series of high-level official contacts to try to stabilize ties between the two rivals as the U.S. heads to elections late in the year. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Secretary of State Antony Blinken went to China in quick succession last April. The South China Sea is only one of the many thorny issues that divide the two major powers and may not even be the most pressing one. On the other hand, Beijing is not budging down and continues to up pressure against its smaller neighbor even in the presence of its big ally. If China’s response to this year’s Balikatan shows the limits of deterrence, the South China Sea may be in for more turbulence.
This article was published by China US Focus
